notes:
1. Concept

Electrical properties determine how a material responds to an electric field. The primary properties are conductivity and its reciprocal, resistivity.

2. Key Properties

  • Conductivity ($\sigma$): A measure of a material's ability to conduct electric current. It is the ratio of the current density to the electric field strength. Units are Siemens per meter (S/m).
  • Resistivity ($\rho$): The reciprocal of conductivity. It measures how strongly a material opposes the flow of electric current. Units are Ohm-meters (Ω·m).

3. Classification of Materials

  • Conductors: Materials with high conductivity and low resistivity (e.g., copper, aluminum, silver). They have many free electrons that can move easily.
  • Insulators (Dielectrics): Materials with low conductivity and high resistivity (e.g., glass, rubber, plastics). Their electrons are tightly bound to atoms and are not free to move.
  • Semiconductors: Materials with intermediate conductivity that can be precisely controlled by adding impurities (doping). They are the basis of all modern electronics (e.g., silicon, germanium).

solvedExamples.question: Which of the following materials is an electrical insulator?
solvedExamples.explanation: Copper and aluminum are excellent conductors. Silicon is a semiconductor. Glass has very high resistivity and is a common electrical insulator.
